The treatise states:
If you wish to grasp the intrinsic nature of the self-nature of the TathÄgata based on the wisdom of worldly truth and various bodies, this becomes my meaning.
Now, in the first truth, observing the TathÄgata, if this wisdom is the essence of the aggregates, it has already been included in the aggregates.
Now, the TathÄgata is refuted, and that wisdom is also refuted.
As the treatise verse says:

The commentary says:
Aggregates means the meaning of accumulation.
The TathÄgata is not the aggregates, because the essence of the TathÄgata is not the aggregates.

Here, a logical argument is presented: in the ultimate truth, the aggregates are not the TathÄgata, because the aggregates are phenomena that arise and cease, like the aggregates of ordinary beings or the external four great elements, etc.
Thus, using because of being produced as the reason, a logical argument will be extensively explained.
Furthermore, the aggregates are not the TathÄgata. This has already been refuted. The arising of dharmas is refuted, as well as real dharmas and the aggregates such as form.

Next, now taking wisdom as one door, separately refuting in the ultimate truth that wisdom is not the TathÄgata, because it is a dharma that arises and ceases, and because it is wisdom, like the wisdom of ordinary beings.
Non-Buddhists and others consider that apart from the aggregates there is a TathÄgata, establishing this as a means to establish a self.

Now answering this, if apart from the aggregates there is a TathÄgata, there is no valid cognition that can bring about understanding. Thus it is not the case that apart from the aggregates there is a TathÄgata.

Mutual non-existence means that within the TathÄgata there are no aggregates, and within the aggregates there is no TathÄgata.ğŸ”½Within the TathÄgata there are no aggregates is like saying that on the Himalayas there are no medicinal herbs, and one cannot say that there are medicinal herbs.
Within the aggregates there is no TathÄgata is like saying that in a forest there are no lions, and one cannot say that there are lions.
The TathÄgata is not one who possesses the aggregates, just as one who is fully endowed with wealth is called one who has wealth, and one who is not fully endowed is not called one who has wealth.
In this way, through five kinds of investigations, the TathÄgata is not established.

As explained, when investigating with skillful means, there is no TathÄgata, just as when many people are captured as thieves, they are considered to be thieves, but when they are examined, they are found to be good people, and there are no real thieves.
In this way, apart from the aggregates, what is a man?
What is self-mastery?
You say that the TathÄgata is not established.ğŸ”½Because what is said is not established, it also lacks a simile.
Because the simile is lacking, there is an error in the proposed thesis.
The SÅ«tra master further says:

The treatise states:
This is not so. What you say then becomes erroneous.
As a treatise verse says:
If the TathÄgata exists due to the aggregates, then he has no self-nature;
If he has no self-nature, how can he depend on others?
The explanation says:
This means that one who has self-nature incurs such faults.
One should understand that the TathÄgata has no self-nature.
Here, a logical argument is presented: in the ultimate truth, the TathÄgata has no self-nature, because he is a hypothetical entity, like a whirling fire wheel;
Because he is unreal, like a pot.
The Abhidharma masters say:

The treatise states:
If pots, etc. are real, they are also unreal, because they are analogies.
However, pots, water, etc. are forms that exist in the conventional truth, but in the ultimate truth, they are unreal.
Why is this?
If a dharma is nonexistent when analyzed, it is conventional truth, up to the final stage of nonexistence, it is also conventional truth.
The Abhidharma masters say:
Just as the five aggregates are provisional, the TathÄgata is also provisional.
Saying that the essence of the TathÄgata is the creator, using such an understanding to establish that the TathÄgata has no essence, on the contrary, establishes my meaning.
Why is it so?
Because the aggregates are created.
If it is said that the TathÄgata arises with others as conditions, such an establishment is also without a metaphor that can serve as a metaphor.
In this way, all that has others as conditions have their own essence, just as the color of a fire wheel is the object of the non-discriminating eye consciousness.
In this way, all that have others as conditions have their own essence. This is how my school establishes the thesis.
The treatise says:
Fire turns up and down everywhere in space, but has no wheel body. Using the empty wheel body as a metaphor is not correct.
The arising of fire and so forth has already been refuted earlier.
In this way, the real dharmas and the various consciousnesses such as eye consciousness and the objects such as form, etc., have all been refuted earlier.
Just as the eye and up to form and all dharmas, they are also refuted in the same way.
If arising depends on causes and conditions, the meaning of having self-nature is not established.
Why is it so?
As the treatise verse says:
Dharmas arise from other conditions, but it is not so for one who has a self;
If there is no self, how can there be a TathÄgata?
The commentary explains:
This means that one who takes others as conditions is a hypothetical case, like an illusory person.
If the TathÄgata has no self-nature, how can he establish the metaphor of all natures having self-nature?
With this intention, the previous metaphor becomes faulty.
Furthermore, your statement that because the TathÄgata has self-nature, all natures can have self-nature, is also not so.
The opponent says:
Although there is not a single thing that can be the TathÄgata, yet the TathÄgata exists. My analogy is successful, and there is no such fault as you have stated.
The treatise states:
This is not so.
Why is it so?
As a treatise verse says:
If there is no intrinsic nature, how can there be an extrinsic nature?
Apart from intrinsic and extrinsic natures, what is the TathÄgata?
The commentary explains:
This means that ultimately there is no TathÄgata.
If you say that apart from intrinsic and extrinsic natures there is a separate TathÄgata nature, in the ultimate truth it is not established, and you are not without fault.
The VÄtsÄ«putrÄ«yas say:

If the TathÄgata is explained in this way, its meaning is established.
The treatise states:
Is the TathÄgata in the ultimate truth grasped based on the aggregates?
Is the TathÄgata's appropriation of the aggregates not the ultimate truth?
If he appropriates the aggregates as the TathÄgata, then appropriation is meaningless.
If it is not the TathÄgata, then I ask for the meaning now.
As the treatise verse says:
Before appropriating the aggregates, there is no TathÄgata;
Now, because of appropriating the aggregates, is he only now the TathÄgata?
The commentary says:
This means that before appropriating the aggregates, there is already a self. The outsider's intention is like this.
The treatise says:
If so, as the treatise verse says:
Before appropriating the aggregates, there is no TathÄgata;

The commentary says:
This means that apart from appropriation, the TathÄgata is not established.

Because the TathÄgata has no self-nature.
As the outsider grasps, the self has no aggregate-nature, and later the self appropriates the TathÄgata's aggregates to become the TathÄgata.
The treatise states:
Now, this self does not take the aggregates of the TathÄgata, because this self is not the TathÄgata, just as other things do not take the aggregates of the TathÄgata as the TathÄgata.
If one takes the aggregates after becoming the TathÄgata, do you wish for that to be so?
As stated in the verse above, it is a mistake.
Now, when asking about the TathÄgata, is it the essence of the aggregates?

If it is the essence of the aggregates, it has already been answered above.
If it is different from the essence of the aggregates, then there is no TathÄgata.
Why is it so?
Because it is not the essence of the aggregates, just like the horns of a rabbit.

It is also as stated above, that in the ultimate truth, before the TathÄgata arises, he is not the TathÄgata, and does not take the aggregates of the TathÄgata, because there is no TathÄgata before he arises, just like one who is not the TathÄgata.
As stated in the treatise verse:

If apart from that taking, there is no place for the TathÄgata.
The commentary states:
This means that apart from grasping, there is no essence of the TathÄgata.

Now, a logical argument will be presented: there is no person in the five aggregates, because they are produced, like a pot.ğŸ”½In the same way, there is no person in dharmas that arise from conditions, because they are produced, like a pot.

The VÄtsÄ«putrÄ«yas say:

The treatise says:
As it is said in the sÅ«tras, there was a king who came and asked the Buddha, saying:

The Buddha said:

The king said:

The non-Buddhist DÄrukará¹‡in says:

That which is not inverted, all dharmas without self-nature, is spoken of by the TathÄgata, and is worshipped by all gods and humans. The TathÄgata is endowed with all-knowledge, the ten powers, fearlessness, and other merits.
Setting aside this matter, I will now return to explaining my own school.
As the treatise verse says:

The commentary explains:

The meaning is as stated in the treatise verse:

The TathÄgata does not have these things.

The treatise says:

Why is this?
As a verse in the treatise says:

The commentary says:
If someone says that apart from the wisdom of hearing, one can attain the ultimate emptiness of all objects, then one does not speak of the emptiness of all dharmas, because there is no such person.
In order to accord with the accumulation of merit and wisdom of the beings to be guided, one speaks of emptiness and so forth, but only conventionally designates them.
In order to wash away the defilements of incorrect discrimination, and in order to break through the cataracts of wrong views and delusion, one speaks of the non-emptiness of all objects.
Why is this?
If emptiness is taught, it increases wrong views.

In the ultimate truth, like an illusion or a mirage, the intrinsic nature is unborn, so both [existence and non-existence] are not taught.

In order to prevent others from establishing proofs, in order to stop the faults of giving rise to the two views regarding objects, and in order to attain the ultimate truth, it is said that there is non-duality.

In this way, in order to wash away the stains of incorrect discrimination, the words of emptiness, signlessness, wishlessness, dreams, illusions, and so forth are spoken. Therefore, it is said that emptiness eliminates all views.
As the treatise verse says:

The commentary states:
This means that if things have their own intrinsic nature, seeing emptiness is of no benefit. In order to destroy that view, emptiness is praised.
The opponent says:

The treatise states:
Your words are not so.
